title: 0 to 500,000 in 21 months: Nissan Qahqai smashes UK car making record in Sunderland
text:
0.0001 0.0000 
Japanese car maker Nissan takes just 21 months to produce 500,000 models of its crossover car at North East plant, breaking British record 
The 500,000th Qashqai cross-over car has rolled off the production line at Nissan’s Sunderland plant, underlining the efficiency of the UK’s biggest car factory. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) took workers just 21 months to achieve the feat, the shortest time for any British-built car to reach the milestone, with a new car being finished every 62 seconds. 
According to the Japanese car company, the previous record was held by Austin/Morris 1100/1300 series at 29 months, followed by Ford’s Mark I Cortina, which took 34 months. 
Of the half million Qahqais built at Sunderland, one in five were sold in the UK, with the vast majority going to export markets including France, Italy and Spain. 
The production landmark supports Nissan’s recent decision to invest £100m in the factory for the equipment to build the next generation of its smaller Juke car there, with the company hailing staff at the North East plant for their productivity. 
However last week’s announcement saw claims that chief executive Carlos Ghosn had been "scaremongering" when he warned that the prospect of Britain leaving the EU or renegotiating its membership terms would cause Nissan to “reconsider” its investments in the UK. 
Launching the Qashqai in London two years ago, Mr Ghosn said: “If anything has to change, we (would) need to reconsider our strategy and our investments for the future. It will have implications, obviously. 
“You cannot consider the UK independent of its environment. If the UK is part of Europe, it’s a completely different situation than if it is not part of Europe.” 
Speaking after last week’s investment announcement, Nissan Europe chairman Paul Willcox was forced to defend the company . He rebuffed questions suggesting that the car-maker had “its bluff called” and the new money going into Sunderland showed that it would have invested in the UK regardless of the forthcoming referendum on Britain’s position within the EU. 
Mr Willcox said the Sunderland plant was a “beacon for global manufacturing and excellence for Nissan” with the 6,700 workers at the factory which has produced more than 8 million cars since opening in 1986 helping create one of the most efficient plants in the world. 
He added: “The two things (investment decisions and the result of the referendum) are not completely linked, as we manage and judge our business on events that we understand. 
“Our position in terms of competitiveness is driven by not only the situation in Europe in terms of whether we are in or out of the EU but more importantly by the commitment of the people we have in the North East and the supply chain we have in the UK.”
